crops.description: "Honey;" introduced from Bulgaria. Mr. H. C. Warner, of the State Board of Agriculture of South Dakota, says: "This pumpkin was tested in comparison with Connectient, Field, Potiron, Etampes, Tours, Large Cheese, Japanese, Cushow, Black Sugar, Gray Bologne, and Pie, and while some of them were more productive, it leads them all in quality. It should be extensively distributed for culinary use and for feeding milch cows." According to Mr. Warner's report this noteworthy snecess was attained in rich, sandy loam; the vines bore drought and the fruit was ripe by the beginning of September. In California this excellence seems not to have been apparent.
"Koch- anka;" a Russian variety. Oval, flesh green; very productive, medium early; sweet and juicy. Extensively used for confectionery, cooked in sugar, the process peculiar.
Russian variety from Belbek, Crimea. Oblong, dark green; flesh bright red; early.
"Empress of Melons;" a Russian variety. Oval, surface variegated, flesh green, delicate, melting, and very sweet; extremely early and productive.
Originally from Yokohama, Japan. Dark green, with red flesh; moderately late.

crops.origin: Lenkoran, Province of Baku, Transcaucasia, Russia
crops.description: "Lenkoran No. 2;" originally from Lenkoran, Province of Baku, in Transcaucasia. Shape, oval; outside bright yellow with small dark spots; flesh green; ripens late and keeps well.
"Favorite of the Pjatigorsk farm;" a Russian variety. Round, skin green with dark stripes, flesh orange; very early. Variety obtained direct from its native locality.
"General Skobeleff II;" an Asiatic variety introduced into Russia from Khiva, Turkestan. Round, rind white, flesh orange; medium early.
"The Czar of Baktcha;" a Russian variety. Very large, bright green with dark stripes, flesh red; rather late.
"Favorite of the Pjatigorsk farm;" a Russian variety. Round, skin green with dark stripes, flesh dark red; very early; further described as "magnificent." Evidently the same as No. 20.
"Jea Teveam;" originally from China. Blackish green, flesh rose-colored; moderately late.
